I am a mover and a shaper, and a people person, who has been activating communities since ages ago. 

By day, I am the Community Manager at Joy Business Academy (JBA) where I am tasked with growing a community to eradicate youth unemployment. JBA is creating a world first 'learning to earning' platform that helps young people develop their employment skills, and then find the rewarding job they've been looking for. To do this, we work with employers to identify the skills their new hires are lacking, and then design online courses for young people to develop those skills. JBA is launching in New Zealand in August, and we plan to quickly scale around the world.

My community experience doesn’t stop there, previously activating a community around investing in growth stage private equity in New Zealand through equity crowdfunding, and local communities around the world in response to natural disasters. 

By night, I am a jack of all trades. As Curator of the Auckland Global Shapers, I am part of a team who are committed to initiating projects to improve Auckland. As a volunteer, I am a fanatical supporter of various organisations including Live More Awesome (which raises awareness for mental health issues) and Make a Wish (which makes wishes of children with life threatening illnesses). And as a human, I am willing to help wherever I can add value.

Dr. Benedict Okey Oramah assumed the position of President of the African Export – Import Bank (Afreximbank) in September 2015. 

Prior to his current role, he was the Executive Vice President in charge of for Business Development and Corporate Banking (BDCB), a position he occupied from October 2008 to September 2015. As Executive Vice President, Dr. Oramah supervised the Business Development functions, namely: Trade Finance, Project and Export development finance, Syndications and Specialized Finance (SSF), and Corporate Finance and Advisory Services (CFAS). He also supervised the Research and Knowledge Management Functions of the Bank. Further, he assisted the then President of the Bank in overseeing the Bank’s Strategic Planning and International Cooperation functions. Dr. Oramah joined Afreximbank as Chief Analyst in 1994 and was promoted to the position of Senior Director, Planning and Business Development in 2007. 

Prior to joining Afreximbank, he held the position of Assistant Research Manager at the Nigerian Export Import Bank (NEXIM) from 1992 to 1994. 

Dr. Oramah holds M.Sc. and Ph.D. Degrees in Agricultural Economics obtained in 1987 and 1991 respectively from Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife, Nigeria. He obtained a B.Sc. degree in Agricultural Economics from the University of Ibadan, Nigeria in 1983. He has published a book on “Foundations of Structured Trade Finance” and has written over 35 articles on a wide range of African economic, trade and trade finance issues. 

He is a regular speaker at several trade and trade finance conferences around the world. Dr. Oramah is Chairperson of the Africa Chapter of the International Factors Group (IFG). He serves on the Board of IFG, the Editorial Boards of Trade and Forfaiting Review (TFR) and the Journal of African Trade (JAT), and is a member of the Consultative Board on the World Cocoa Economy of the International Cocoa Organization (ICCO).

He is married and has three children.

Gerardo Adesso's main interests are in the characterisation of quantum correlations in composite systems, be them in the form of entanglement or more general types such as quantum discord. He has contributed significantly to the development of quantum information theory with Gaussian states of continuous variable systems.
His research is mainly devoted to the identification and quantification of genuinely quantum resources for efficient quantum information technology. He is interested in understanding the most essential signatures of quantumness in elementary and complex systems, so as to cast light on foundational aspects of quantum theory, while devising novel ways to exploit quantumness operationally for robust applications. He has studied entanglement and quantum correlations in general, in discrete as well as continuous variable multipartite quantum systems (encompassing atoms, light, and interfaces thereof).

The proteins that regulate chromatin structure in the early embryo, or the way in which the chromatin is remodelled throughout preimplantation development are largely unknown. We are currently devoted to understand how the structure of the chromatin is established at the beginning of embryonic development and how it supports totipotency.
Research in our group focusses on understanding how early mouse development is regulated by chromatin-mediated changes in gene regulation, that is, by epigenetic information. In particular, we are interested in understanding how the transitions in cell potency and cell fate are regulated by chromatin-mediated processes. 
Our work will also allow new insights in understanding the biology of the pluripotent stem cells, in particular on their origin and development. From a broader perspective, deciphering the basic mechanisms underlying the earliest steps of mammalian development is essential to understand early aspects of embryonic development, human reproduction and stem cell biology.

Bachelor’s in Electrical Engineering, Cooper Union; Master’s in Bioelectrical Engineering, MIT; PhD in Biomedical Engineering and MBA, Columbia University. PhD research focused on studying electrical signalling in the context of tissue engineering; has worked with cardiac, skin, bone and neural tissue. Chief Executive Officer and Co-Founder, EpiBone, the world’s first company growing living human bones for skeletal reconstruction. TED Senior Fellow. Adjunct Professor of Electrical Engineering, Cooper Union. Co-Author of Super Cells: Building with Biology, a book that explores the new frontier of biotech.

Van Kasteren's research may well contribute to the development of more effective vaccines against cancer. He makes new substances and tests these in model vaccines to find out whether receptors (proteins that transmit signals from inside or outside the cell) recognise sugars and can detect differences in sugar patterns. The aim is to find out whether some sugar patterns activate the immune system against cancer better than others. He focuses on developing new chemical tricks to study and manipulate the immune system. The techniques he uses are a combination of organic synthesis, cell biology and immunology.

profile:

Quite often he encounters interesting phenomena in these biological systems that he enjoys applying to medical, environmental, and energy related problems.
positionTitle: Associate Professor, Department of Biological Sciences and Department of Physics

profile:
Amanda Randles' work focuses on the design of large-scale parallel applications targeting problems in physics.  Her research goals are to both investigate fundamental questions related to fluid dynamics as well as extend the multiscale models developed in her thesis to study cancer metastasis.
She designs large-scale parallel applications that enable the study of research problems in areas ranging from cardiovascular disease to wireless networks to drug development.

Speech processing technology will move to a new level of social awareness to make interaction more intuitive, speech retrieval more efficient, and enhance computer-mediated communication and speech-analysis services. To reach this goal, rich speaker traits and personal states carried by the tone of the voice and the spoken words must be reliably identified by machines. In Schuller’s iHEARu project, ground-breaking methodology including novel techniques for multi-task and semi-supervised learning will deliver for the first time intelligent holistic and evolving analysis in real-life condition of universal speaker characteristics which have been considered only in isolation so far. Today's sparseness of annotated realistic speech data will be overcome by large-scale speech and meta-data mining from public sources such as social media, crowd-sourcing for labelling and quality control, and shared semi-automatic annotation.

Associate professor in the Department of Physics. Graduated in Physics in 2000 at the University of Naples "Federico II". He received his PhD in 2004 with a thesis in experimental quantum optics, with contributions on quantum teleportation and cloning. He has received several awards, including Premio Sapio Junior per la Ricerca Italiana, the Medal "Le Scienze in Fisica" with the "Medal of the Presidency of the Republic », Award Sapienza Ricerca. He is the author of more than 120 publications in international journals (among which 20 publications on Nature and Science journals) and about 100 invited presentations at national and international conferences. Since 2009, Fabio Sciarrino has obtained fundings for the University of Roma “La Sapienza” as principal investigator for a total amount of more than 3.500.000 euros (approx. 3.100.000 from Europe and 400.000 from Italy). In 2010 he won the project HYTEQ (Hybrid Technologies for Quantum Information Processing) funded by FIRB - Future in Research for young Italian researchers. In 2012 he was awarded an ERC grant Starting Grant-Consolidator 3D-QUEST (www.3dquest.eu), followed by an ERC-Proof of Concept 3D-COUNT in 2015: 3D-Integrated single photon detector. He is the european coordinator of the project Marie Curie Initial Training Networks (ITN): PICQUE (Photonic Integrated Compound Quantum Encoding) started September 2013 (www.picque.eu). He is the european coordinator of the project FET (Future and Emerging Technologies): QUCHIP (Quantum Simulation on a Photonic Chip) . He has the lecture in Quantum Information and Computation at the University "La Sapienza". His research has been devoted mainly to the experimental realization of quantum information protocols by exploiting the methods of quantum optics. To achieve his results has required the development of innovative experimental techniques based on non-linear optics, ultra-fast lasers and detection methods, as well as of new theoretical insights. The results of his investigations have advanced the experimental techniques of quantum optics and contributed to understanding some conceptual aspects of the foundations of quantum mechanics and quantum information theory. His current research activity is focused on integrated quantum photonics, specifically on the implementation of boson sampling and quantum simulation.

The computational power of quantum computers is exponentially proportional to the number of quantum bits, endorsed by the coherent superposition of quantum states. We cannot imagine future quantum computers composed of hundreds of optical tables with millions of bulk optical device, and hundreds of scientists working on the maintenance. Xianmin Jin is thus developing quantum integrated photonics, an elegant way to find a solution to the limitation of computational power of human beings. He is also leading a project on developing on-chip quantum terminal, which would facilitate quantum communication ensuring the unconditional security of private communication for the first time.
positionTitle: Professor; Founder, Laboratory of Quantum Integrated Photonics

profile: Dr. Madan co-founded Ginger.io and as its CEO currently leads overall product vision and business strategy. He has extensive research experience in modeling large-scale human behavior data using statistical models and pattern recognition technology. His past research has been featured in academic publications in computer science and is frequently cited in popular media and press. He received his PhD from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in the Media Lab with Dr. Alex Pentland. Dr. Madan is a frequent international speaker on the topics of behavioral analytics, machine learning, data privacy and healthcare entrepreneurship.

Neven Karlovac was one of the technical and business leaders in the US who took fiberoptic communications from the lab and transformed them into a global telecommunications network.
Today his passion is to make medical diagnostics accessible and affordable for everyone using the best photonic and mobile Internet technologies.
Neven hails from Croatia, where he obtained his
BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering
from the University of Zagreb. He earned his PhD from the University of Tennessee at Knoxville.

Degree in Economics, University of Waterloo; degree in Philosophy and Political Science, University of British Columbia; Graduate Studies Program, studying exponential technologies at NASA Ames research centre, Singularity University; 2011, graduate degree in Financial Engineering, MS&E programme, Stanford, Hong Kong. Has worked with a range of organizations, from the earliest stage start-ups to the largest scale institutions. At 19, Junior Economist, Canadian Federal Government; then with Quack.com, Waterloo, Ontario; after Quack was acquired by America Online, by age 20, member of the inaugural team, AOL Time Warner's Voice Services Division, focused on speech recognition analysis. Founded a group of small companies and experimented with a number of technologies. 2010, Co-Founder, Satellogic nanosatellites; 2011, Founding Partner, Minor Capital VCC investments. 2012, Co-Founder and Chief Executive Officer, 1QBit. Interests: quantum computation; kayaking in the gulf islands; exploring practical applications of microbiology at a small home laboratory on Vancouver Island dedicated to experiments with saccharomyces cerevisiae.

Degrees in Economics, University of Oxford and Columbia College, New York. Economist. Spent nearly a decade at Oracle following positions with the Texas Pacific Group and Morgan Stanley & Co. Currently, Chief Executive Officer, Alation, which helps businesses better find, understand and use internal data.

Entrepreneur.  More than a decade of experience growing successful technology companies. Co-Founder and Chief Executive Officer, Axcient, the award winning leader in cloud-based Recovery-as-a-Service; has led the transformation of the data backup and business continuity industry to end data loss and IT downtime for businesses. Member of the boards and councils of private and public companies. Award-winning mentor to young entrepreneurs.

Jacob de Geer is a Swedish serial entrepreneur and co-founder and CEO of iZettle, the fastgrowing mobile payments company that lets anyone take card payments and manage and grow their business.
Before starting iZettle, Jacob was the first employee at performance marketing firm TradeDoubler. Here he helped to build one of the largest advertising networks in Europe before
leaving to co-found movie sharing firm, Ameibo, and Tre Kronor Media, an award-winning communications agency. Both companies were acquired in 2010.
Now, Jacob is fully focused on democratising payments around the world through his latest venture, iZettle.

Ms. Yang Hao, is a development professional specialized in programme development and management, capacity building, research and advocacy in areas of gender equality, women’s empowerment and child rights. She has experience working with the UN and international development organizations both in China and abroad. As Monitoring, Evaluation and Research Manager for Plan International in China and gender equality advisor for Voluntary Service Overseas in Nepal, Ms. Hao provided guidance on strategic planning, programming and advocacy to promote child rights and gender equality in basic education, child protection, sexual and reproductive health, livelihood, disaster risk management and early childhood care and development. She has also served for UN Women, in charge of programme portfolios to address issues of violence against women, migrant workers’ labor rights, women’s political participation, HIV/AIDS, climate change and disaster risk reduction. Ms. Hao holds a Master of Science degree from the London School of Economics and Political Science.

Nearly 20 years in Japan in senior management and director-level positions with Datacraft Japan, PTS eSafe Japan, a niche technology services company servicing foreign multi-nationals in Japan, and Dell Japan; launched Dell into the Japanese market. 2007, co-founded Global Business Register, which specializes in identity and compliance solutions for companies; currently, Chief Operating Officer. 2013, founded Sedicii, which allows the authentication of individuals, using a novel technology called zero knowledge proof, where identity can be proven without exposing priv. Mentor, Enterprise Ireland, providing advice to high-potential start-up companies. Active investor in various start-up companies in the technology and biotech spaces.

Dr. Leslie Dewan is a co-founder and Chief Executive Officer of Transatomic Power, a nuclear reactor design company developing sustainable power plants that can consume existing stockpiles of nuclear waste. She received her Ph.D. in nuclear engineering from MIT in 2013, with a research focus on computational nuclear materials. She also holds S.B. degrees from MIT in mechanical and nuclear engineering. She is a member of the MIT Corporation, MIT’s board of trustees. She has been named a TIME Magazine "30 People Under 30 Changing the World," an MIT Technology Review "Innovator Under 35," and a National Geographic Emerging Explorer.

Jun works as a senior strategy manager at 17zuoye, a DST-backed D-round startup in online education. Jun receives her education from the London School of Economics and has prior experience in hedge fund and management consulting.

Jun is actively engaged in local startup and volunteering communities. profile:
With extensive experience in the world of Structured Finance and Export Credit, Michal Ron is currently Managing Director - Head of International Business in SACE, overseeing the Group’s International Relations, Overseas Network and Political Credit Recovery. Her responsibilities include all activities related to the Paris Club and other political recoveries, with a track history of € 10 Bn in sovereign recoveries over the past years and the achievement of successful results in post-sanctions contexts such as Argentina, Cuba and Iran, paving the way for these countries to regain access to international markets. Over the past 7 years, Michal has steered the expansion of SACE’s overseas network, supervising international underwriting generated by the 10 offices abroad (Bucharest, Dubai, Istanbul, Hong Kong, Johannesburg, Mexico City, Moscow, Mumbai, Nairobi, Sao Paulo). She also manages SACE’s role within the OECD and EU, Reinsurance Agreements and the overall relationship with other Export Credit Agencies. In 2014 she has been elected to the role of Vice President of the Berne Union, and reconfirmed in the same position in October 2015. In her capacity as Berne Union Vice President she has led numerous initiatives, including the Outreach Working Group between the Berne Union and the World Bank.
Prior to working at SACE, she spent 10 years at MCC SpA (Head of Oil, Gas and Petrochemicals, Structured Finance) and 7 years with HSBC (London, Madrid, Milan). With a Business Studies, Risk Management and Finance BSc Honors degree from City University Business School (London), Michal has worked in investment banking in several European countries and has been invited to speak in numerous business conferences worldwide.She is based in Rome, Italy (SACE’s Headquarters).”

Deepak Krishnamurthy is the Chief Strategy Officer and the Head of Corporate Strategy at SAP. 

Reporting to Bill McDermott, the CEO of SAP, Deepak is responsible for shaping overall SAP strategy.

His primary focus is to identify short-term and long-term growth drivers that drive significant value creation for customers, partners, shareholders and employees. Deepak also coordinates strategic planning for SAP’s growth areas jointly with the SAP CFO and the Products & Innovation group.
Deepak’s responsibilities include:
- Develop corporate strategy including financial plans, investment priorities, growth drivers, and business transformation
- Oversee market intelligence and insight
- Identify and incubate new business models
- Drive M&A strategy jointly with Corporate Development
- Communicate strategy internally and externally

Since joining SAP in September 2009, Deepak has led multiple strategic initiatives for SAP including:
- M&A strategy that resulted in the acquisitions of SuccessFactors, Ariba and Concur
- Leading worldwide GTM strategy to drive innovation execution
- SAP’s transformation to a Cloud company 

Prior to SAP, Deepak was an Engagement Manager at McKinsey & Company advising clients in the high tech and healthcare industries. Deepak started his career at Cognizant Technology Solutions where he held multiple leadership positions including leading Business Development for their Business Analytics practice.

Deepak holds an MBA from the Indian Institute of Management, Calcutta, as well as a Bachelor in Chemical and Electrochemical Engineering from Central Electrochemical Research Institute in India.

Deepak is based in SAP’s New York City office.

1984, BSc, 1986, MSc and 1996, PhD in Information Science, Tokyo Institute of Technology. 1994, joined Sony Computer Science Laboratories (Sony CSL); 1999, formed and directed the Interaction Laboratory within Sony CSL; since 2011, Deputy Director. Since 2007, Professor, Interfaculty Initiative in Information Studies, University of Tokyo. Academy Member, ACM SIGCHI. Has published more than 100 articles in the area of human-computer interactions. Research topics: human-computer interaction; augmented reality, virtual reality, human augmentation, telepresence, smart environments; hybrid intelligence. Research interests include human-computer interaction, computer augmented environments and computer augmented human (human-computer integration). Has invented various innovative interactive systems and sensing technologies, including NaviCam (a hand-held AR system), Pick-and-Drop (a direct-manipulation technique for inter-appliance computing), CyberCode (the world’s first marker-based AR system), Augmented Surfaces, HoloWall, and SmartSkin (two earliest representations of multi-touch systems). Recipient: Multi-Media Grand Prix Technology Award, Multi-Media Contents Association Japan (1998); iF Interaction Design Award (2000); Japan Inter-Design Award (2003); iF Communication Design Award (2005); Good Design Best 100 Award (2012); Japan Society for Software Science and Technology Fundamental Research Award (2012); ACM UIST Lasting Impact Award, Zoom Japon Les 50 qui font le Japon de demain (2013).

Ken Ho joined BT in August 2015 as Managing Director of China, BT Global Services, focusing on the mainland Chinese market. He is responsible for all of BT’s sales and business operations activities in China.

James Song is a managing principal and co-founder of Faircap Partners, a US-based investment advisory responsible for building and supporting the nascent democracy in Myanmar. Specifically, James designs and structures deals in infrastructure and industry that bridge the gap between Myanmar’s rich and poor, creating substantial value for investors while providing crucial resources to disadvantaged and marginalized Burmese communities. Previously, he was principal and founder of Fury Capital, an event-driven special-situations hedge fund, where James applied his extensive analytical skills to uncover deep-value inefficiencies in U.S. securities.

As a Fulbright scholar in Uganda, James pioneered the use of empirically-based, non-pharmacological HIV interventions at Makerere University Hospital. He stayed in Uganda following his research to build the country's first polyethylene recycling facility, Song Industrial, which would later spur the creation of the plastic recycling industry in East Africa.

James graduated salutatorian from Harvard University, and received an MSc in neuroscience from University College London.

We are committed to provide consumers with high quality, healthy and reliable organic products. As of today we have fulfilled organic food home delivery services to over 500,000 families in 6 metropolitan cities including Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Hangzhou, and Tianjin. Bringing more than 20 years’ experience in emerging markets, as well as 32 years in global agri-business, Robert Aspell is recognized as a strategic leader with a proven record for growing businesses, talent development and building highly engaged organization, consequently enabling sustainable growth for the company.
After a decade in the trading sphere where he led Cargill’s global feed grains trading from its trading hub in Geneva, he took on the challenge of developing Cargill’s presence in Egypt as a founding member. Further on in his tenure as President of Cargill Mexico, he helped develop the business from an agency model to an integrated business model linked to Cargill’s global supply chain with processing/trading activities, acquisitioning key assets, and partnerships that triggered significant growth. Furthermore, he also led Cargill’s entrance in Mexico’s food sector, which positioned Cargill as one of the major suppliers of food ingredients in this country.
Since his arrival in China in 2005, under his leadership, Cargill China’s total business increased over twentyfold, and he has also helped lead the development of a large and capable talent pool. Recently, Cargill China was awarded Best Employer in China by Aon Hewitt. He was appointed the President of Cargill China since 2010.
His experience has enabled him to develop a rare mix of deep understanding of risk management, business development and as a Country Leader/BU leader for nearly 20 years in different regions of the world, where he has proven a capable leader of a diverse group of people. Robert is an avid student of China and remains firmly optimistic about the potential of the Chinese market and advocates that with the current reforms the industry performance will improve significantly in years ahead. He initiated Cargill China 2020 Aspiration championing “grow together with China”, which focuses on strategic investment, trusted partnership building, talent cultivation and continuous improvement. Under his leadership, the startup business of Grains & Oilseeds in China turned largely profitable in its
2nd year of operations, and over the decade, this business is largely recognized as the industry leader.
In belief of growing together with the home market where Cargill invests, Robert Aspell initiated and led the strategic partnership programs with Chinese policy-makers in exchanging world-class best practices and knowledge on food security and food safety, as well as sharing Cargill’s practices from a business perspective. With his support, Cargill China established systematic community outreach program with more than 33 Cargill China Care Councils running over 40+ cities in the country. Robert Aspell also championed a series of campaigns to cultivate talents in agriculture and food areas.
As a keen sportsman, Robert created the Shanghai Youth Ice Hockey program in 2006, which has grown significantly since. Although he left its Presidency in 2011, he is very proud to have had an impact on Shanghai youth. He himself still plays ice hockey, cycles and trains regularly.
Robert obtained a bachelor’s degree in Business from Concordia University in Montreal Canada in 1983. He lives in Shanghai.

profile: Tolu Oni is a Senior Lecturer at the School of Public Health and Family Medicine, University of Cape Town. As a Public Health Medical Specialist and Urban Epidemiologist, she is a passionate advocate of health equity and health in all policies. Her research focuses on understanding the interactions between health risk and profiles (including the overlap between infectious and non-communicable diseases) and the urban and urbanising environment, with a view to community level intersectoral interventions. As a member and co-Chair of the South African Young Academy of Science (www.sayas.org), she works actively to encourage public engagement and a cross disciplinary discourse on the determinants of health; and to engage public, private, academic, governmental and non-governmental sectors in the translation of research findings into policy and practice. She is a Next Einstein Forum Fellow (http://nef.org/nef-fellows/), and a World Economic Forum Young Scientist; and aims to promote science and research as key drivers of development in Africa.
positionTitle: Senior Lecturer, Division of Public Health Medicine, School of Public Health

profile:
Mohlopheni Jackson Marakalala is a research fellow in immunology and infectious diseases at Harvard School of Public Health. His research is focused on the development of therapeutic and diagnostic tools to fight tuberculosis. Jackson earned his Doctorate degree in chemical pathology at the University of Cape Town. His doctoral research was awarded with the Bronte Stewart Research Prize for the most meritorious thesis submitted by a doctoral student in 2008.

Jackson has published in high-impact, peer-reviewed journals and has presented his work at international conferences. He has received a number of funding grants and numerous awards for his scientific work and voluntary work. He was the founding chairperson of the Health Sciences Postdoctoral Association at the University of Cape Town and also served as workshops chair and secretary of the Harvard School of Public Health Postdoctoral Association.

Jackson currently represents postdoctoral scientists in the Dean’s Advisory Committee on Diversity and Inclusion at Harvard School of Public Health. In 2010, Jackson received the Sydney Brenner Fellowship that is awarded by the Academy of Science of South Africa to an outstanding young scientist conducting research in South Africa. In June 2012, he was selected to represent South Africa at the Lindau Nobel Laureate meeting in Germany, where he was also chosen to take part in a Nature.com panel discussion alongside two Nobel laureates on ‘the role of science in the developing world’. The German state of Baden-Wuttenburg also selected Jackson to take part in a week-long programme, where he visited more than 10 scientific institutions in the region.

In 2014, Jackson was part of the first-ever Commonwealth Science Conference that was aimed at using science to tackle problems in Commonwealth countries. He was specially invited to the 2015 Commonwealth Day reception in London where he met Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and The Duke of Edinburgh.

Komminist (Kommy) Weldermariam was born in Arba Minch, Ethiopia in a low-income family setting. Determined to get out of his harsh living conditions, he turned to education. His drive and an insatiable curiosity of how things worked led him to science. Kommy earned his Bachelor’s degree in computer science from Addis Ababa University, Ethiopia and Master’s degree in technology from India Institute of Technology, Bombay. He earned his Doctorate degree from Trento University, Italy.

Kommy’s education and research career in development is focused on creating innovative solutions that impact lives. He is developing evidence-based solutions that aim to transform education in Africa by individualizing its delivery to each child. Success in education will create future African scientists and create citizens that can compete and position the continent on a global level.

Kommy has co-authored more than 55 scientific articles based on projects in the areas of software systems, security and education technologies. He has served as scientific committee and organizer for various conferences worldwide. He is a recipient of several awards including paper based awards, and the Experienced Level and Managerial Recognition awards from IBM.

1990, BA in Physics and Astronomy, Wellesley College; 1997, PhD in Physics, MIT. Former Postdoctoral Associate, then Research Scientist, Caltech, working on the Laser Interferometric Gravitational Wave Observatory (LIGO). January 2002, joined the Physics faculty, MIT; since 2015, Associate Head, Department of Physics. Has been involved with LIGO since early years in graduate school at MIT and primary research has been in instrument development for interferometric gravitational-wave detectors. Research focuses on interferometric gravitational waves and quantum measurement. The major US effort in this field is LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory), scheduled to come on the air in 2002. The gravitational waves that LIGO and its international counterparts expect to detect are ripples in the space-time fabric caused by the motion of compact, massive astrophysical objects. Since the nature of gravitation is inherently different from electromagnetism, gravitational wave astrophysics has the potential to provide a radically different view of the universe, including direct observation of massive dark matter, large-scale nuclear matter and a test of strong-field gravitation.

He is passionate about supporting leaders to align the energy, mindset and behaviours of the people across the organisation to support successful strategic execution.
Based in London, Dustin consults with CEOs and their senior teams across the globe. Clients include: Anglo American, Airbus UK, Birds Eye iglo, British Gas, British Telecom, FirstGroup, GlaxoSmithKline, Honda UK, PepsiCo International, Reckitt Benckiser, T-Mobile International AG, United Utilities and Rolls-Royce.
Dustin has led for-profit and not-for-profit organisations and has corporate experience in public relations, marketing, banking and capital fundraising. This varied experience has taught him that healthy, authentic leadership can profoundly and positively impact the culture and performance of any organisation. His work in banking has also provided valuable insights into the daily operations of financial institutions and large corporations.
Dustin is a graduate of the University of California Santa Barbara, where he studied economics and pre-law. He lives in London and is regularly published and is frequently invited to speak to business groups and organisations about purposeful leadership and improving culture and performance.

profile: MSc in Applied Mathematics, University of Lisbon; PhD in Computer Science (artificial intelligence and operations research), University of Edinburgh. Professor of Computer Science, Cornell University, with joint appointments in the Dept. of Computer Science, Dept. of Information Science, and the Dyson School of Applied Economics and Management. Lead PI, NSF Expeditions in Computing award on Computational Sustainability; Director, Institute for Computational Sustainability, Cornell University. Fellow: Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AAAI); American Association for the Advancement of Science. Research has covered several areas in artificial intelligence and computer science, including the integration of constraint reasoning, operations research, and machine learning techniques to solve scale constraint reasoning and optimization problems, complete randomized search methods, and algorithm portfolios, planning and scheduling, and multi agent systems. Central research themes are the integration of concepts from constraint and logical reasoning, mathematical programming, and machine learning, for large scale combinatorial problems; the study of the impact of structure on problem hardness; and the use of randomization techniques to improve the performance of exact (complete) search methods. Also researches computational sustainability.

Professor of Soil and Water Management with extension, research and teaching duties; works on approaches to precision soil management, with current emphases on a holistic soil health management framework, and a computational tool for precision nitrogen management (Adapt-N) that was recently commercialized. Has published over 110 peer-reviewed papers and chapters, co-authored Building Soils for Better Crops, a widely-read book on sustainable soil management, developed numerous extension articles and videos, and advised 45 graduate students.

Russell Frew currently serves as the Vice President & Chief Engineer for the corporation. In this capacity he oversees engineering and program performance and engages directly when technical or programmatic issues arise. He frequently leads teams of experts that tackle some of the corporation’s most challenging engineering issues using 40 plus years of experience in complex technology program development. He additionally serves as the senior executive for Cyber technology development programs. Mr. Frew served as Vice President, Chief Technology Officer (CTO) for Lockheed Martin Electronic Systems from 2003 to 2013. In this capacity he oversaw both technology development and the program performance of over 18,000 engineers and 1400 programs. As CTO, he was responsible for technology strategy and the research investment plan. Additionally, Mr. Frew had executive responsibility for the LM Advanced Technology Laboratories (ATL), an applied research f acility that develops advanced technology hardware and software solutions for varied defense applications. Mr. Frew’s previous assignments include Vice President, Advanced Technology for Naval Electronics & Sensor Systems (NESS); Vice President, Technology for Government Electronics Systems (GES), and Managing Director of the Advanced Technology Laboratories. Mr. Frew has lead technology teams supporting the F-22 Raptor, F-35 Joint Strike Fighter, F-16 Falcon, and C-130J. As part of the Commercial Off-the-Shelf (COTS) revolution, he led the Lockheed Martin Proven Path program, which evolved into an engineering discipline now being widely applied across Department of Defense (DoD) platforms. Beginning in 1988, Mr. Frew managed the GE Aerospace, Artificial Intelligence lab for eight years. There he oversaw activities in antisubmarine warfare, attack helicopter sensor-based reasoning, expert systems, and real-time embedded architect ures. He was instrumental in getting the Sea Shadow prototype stealth ship operational then used this platform to test advanced technology concepts at sea. In 1985 the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) selected him as one of their Program Managers for the national Strategic Computing program to defeat Japan’s Fifth Generation challenge. Mr. Frew lead machine intelligence research programs that helped define the SC initiative. Mr. Frew holds graduate and undergraduate degrees. He has served as a study board member at the National Academy of Sciences and on the Penn University Graduate Engineering School Advisory Board. He additionally spent 4 years as a DARPA ISAT board member and study lead for the Director of DARPA. Mr. Frew currently is the Chairman of the Board of Directors for Technology Ventures Corp, is a Board Member for the Applied NanoStructured Solutions LLC and formerly served on the Board of Directors of th e ISX Corporation. Mr. Frew served in the military for 20 years as a military intelligence officer. He is a lifelong aviator having soloed on his 16th birthday and is currently rated as a multiengine commercial pilot.

Current research interests include: 1) Developing Patient-specific Bone Surgery Protocols; 2) Novel 3D Printing Technologies for Surgeon Training; 3) 3D Printing of Hierarchical Fibre-reinforced Soft Composites for Biological Tissue and Sensing Applications; 4) Big Data Analytics for Part-qualification in Metal Additive Manufacturing ; and (5) Life-cycle Enhancement of High-performance Micro-parts Using Graphene-based Lubricants. A seasoned healthcare executive, Wendy Perchick has decades of experience managing major shifts in the delivery of clinical care for cancer patients.
Today, as Senior Vice President of Strategy and Innovation at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, she plays a pivotal role in charting the organization’s strategic direction as it combines its unique focus and global leadership in cancer care and research with the power of data and analytics. Ms. Perchick is the executive in charge of several initiatives which aim to expand access to leading cancer care, including the expansion of MSK’s overall clinical enterprise as new facilities begin operations, the collaboration with IBM Watson to develop an oncology decision-support tool for physicians anywhere, and the MSK Cancer Alliance which establishes dynamic partnerships with local care providers.
Ms. Perchick has held many different roles since joining MSK in 1976. She combines deep knowledge of hospital operations with a track record of developing innovative models for improving patient care. In 1999, for example, she opened MSK’s first freestanding ambulatory care facility and led the implementation of a fully electronic medical record for the vast majority of MSK’s ambulatory care services.
In addition to significant operational responsibilities, Ms. Perchick leads a diverse group of quantitative analysts and design-research professionals within the Office of Strategy and Innovation. The team’s quantitative work, recognized in 2012 with the INFORMS Prize, has enabled MSK to create models for everything from optimal treatment pathways to potential locations for ambulatory care sites.

profile:
BA (Hons) Biological Sciences, 2001, DPhil in Biophysics, 2007, St John's College, University of Oxford. Postdoctoral Scientist, 2007-2015, Max Planck Institute of Biophysics, Frankfurt am Main, Germany. Now Staff Scientist, Lawrence Berkeley National Labs, California, US.

Myriad cellular and metabolic processes govern the transformation of energy in living organisms. By understanding the structure of cellular structures engaged in the bioenergetic activities, Karen Davies gains insight into their functions. Davies' lab studies the biogenesis of bioenergetic compartments and how the structure of these specific areas change in response to environmental conditions such as light, temperature, and nutrient availability. Using electron cryo-tomography with sub-tomogram averaging in conjunction with single particle electron cryo-microscopy, Davies aims to determine how the structure and organization of proteins in situ influence cellular structure and function. In particular, she seeks to uncover the role of enzymes in shaping mitochondrial cristae, bioenergetic membranes important in the process of cellular respiration. Besides studying bioenergetic compartment design and assembly, Davies delves deeper into cellular chemical reactions like photosynthesis by studying the role of NADH and NADPH dehydrogenases in carbon fixation.

profile:
BSc (Hons) Biology, 2002, University of Bristol, UK. MRes Bioinformatics, 2003, University of Exeter, UK. PhD Plant Physiology, 2008, University of Cambridge, UK. 2007-2013, Research Associate, University of Cambridge, UK. 2013-2014, RIKEN FPR Research Fellow, Centre for Sustainable Resource Science, Yokohama, Japan. Now Director of Plant Systems Biology. Joint BioEnergy Institute (JBEI), Lawrence Berkeley National Lab, USA.

Sugars are one of the fundamental building blocks of life. Whether glycosylating proteins or lipids, or as complex polysaccharides, they are essential to the health of the cell. However, unlike, DNA and protein, these complex sugar molecules are built without an apparent template. An enormous number of combinations are possible due to the different starting molecules (monosaccharides) and the myriad ways they can be linked together. We know that assembly is carefully controlled by the organism, since serious pathologies can result when this process goes wrong. Yet, we know surprisingly little about how this happens.

Mortimer's research focus is to understand the mechanisms that drive glycan assembly. This includes making the substrates (the nucleotide sugars), transporting them to the correct compartment in the cell, and then synthesizing the macromolecules. Questions about how these processes are regulated, as well as how the completed molecules are exported to the wall are essential if we want to engineer biomass to produce the fuels and materials that we will require in the future.
positionTitle: Director, Plant Systems Biology, Joint BioEnergy Institute

Mr. Yousef A. Al-Ulyan is currently Executive
Director of Information Technology for Saudi
Aramco.
Al-Ulyan graduated from King Fahd
University of Petroleum and Minerals in 1984
with a bachelor’s of science and technology
degree in computer science.
He joined the company in 1987 as an
electronic data processing (EDP) systems
analyst. He had several acting assignments
as division head in various divisions within IT
including the Data Management Division and
Data Network Support Division.
In 1999, he joined the SAP Computer Center,
where he held positions as an EDP
applications and systems consultant. He was
charged with establishing the new computing
infrastructure to run the SAP systems and
was part of the team for the SAP Big Bang
deployment. He continued working with the
SAP Computer Center in various roles,
including acting manager of the Enterprise
Computing Department, before being
assigned as the manager o f the Computer
Operations Department in 2007.
In 2010, he was named acting manager for
Support Services Application Department
until October 2011, when he was named as
acting manager of EXPEC Network Operation
Department. During 2010 and 2011, he acted
as general manager at EXPEC Computer
Center, and again acted as general manager
in January 2012. He was appointed general
manager, EXPEC Computer Center, in June
2012.
Al-Ulyan held acting assignments as
Information Technology executive director in
2012 and again acted as executive director in
October 2015 until his permanent
appointment in May 2016.
Al-Ulyan has taken part in management
development activities throughout his career.
He attended SAMDS, completed the
Executive University Program from INSEAD
Business School in France in 2008 and
attended Oxford Energy Seminars at Oxford
University in 2013. Al-Ulyan served for three
years as a Board Member on Aramco
Services Company Board of Directors.

Mati is the Chief Operations Officer of Global
Legal Group and Senior Director of Government
Affairs at Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd., a
global Israeli based healthcare company which
develops, manufactures and markets
pharmaceuticals, active pharmaceutical
ingredients and healthcare solutions. He is also a licensed Lawyer and served as the
Executive Director of the Australian Israel
Leadership Forum. Mati is an active social
entrepreneur in the Israeli community including
co-founding of the "Sanhedrin Forum" for young
Israeli professionals. Until March 2009, Mati served as Chief of Staff
of Israel's Minister of Public Security Mr. Avi
Dichter, a position in which he was in charge of
management of the Minister's public agenda and
office, and advised on professional, political,
communications and international affairs. A
reserve officer at the rank of Major in the IDF,
Mati served as Liaison Officer with United
Nations Peacekeeping Forces in Lebanon and the
Golan Heights, with the United States Army
during operation "Iraqi Freedom" and with the
Jordanian Army in joint efforts to secure the
border.
positionTitle: Chief Operating Officer, Global Legal Group; Senior Director, Government Affairs

Jeremy Stevens is international economist for the
Standard Bank Group, based in Beijing, He
advises Standard Bank’s clients and African
central banks, policymakers and corporates on
developments in the Chinese economy and
financial markets. In addition, he works with
Chinese corporates, policy banks and think tanks
on pportunities in Africa. Jeremy frequently
comments across a host of international media forums.
